text:
Ms. [**Known lastname 7451**] is a 79F with h/o DM, MGUS, and pulmonary fibrosis not on
   O2 at home who was admitted [**5-20**] with progressive fatigue and malaise
   progressive over several months' time.
   .
   Vitals on presentation to the ED were 98.4 P 76 BP 176/80 RR 18 and O2
   sat 86% on room air. CBC was notable for WBC of 15, and she had a large
   R sided infiltrate. She was started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin for
   presumed community-acquired pneumonia and admitted to the medical floor
   for further management. Her course on the floor was notable for O2
   requirement of 5-6L via nasal canula, but she was otherwise clinically
   stable. The morning of transfer, she experienced an increased O2
   requirement, dropping to 84% on 6L NC with improvement to the low 90's
   on a non-rebreather. Given her worsened hypoxemia, she was transferred
   to the ICU for closer monitoring. Labs the day of transfer notable for
   Hct drop 23->19 for which she was transfused with 1 U PRBC and almost
   all of an additional unit until she showed s/s of ? reaction.
   Pneumonia, bacterial, community acquired (CAP)
   Assessment:
   Received pt on NRB 100% with Sp02 96%, intermittent exp wheezes in
   upper fields with fine crackles at bases. RR 20
s with increases to
   30
s after turning. Dry cough. Tmax 100.1 orally; WBC increased to 16.6
   Action:
   Out of bed to chair with nurse assist- tolerated transfer well but c/o
   fatigue after an hour. Switched 02 to High flow neb at 100%. CT of
   chest w/o contrast. Frequent turns. Encouraged CDB and IS. Abx. BC x1,
   Tylenol given for temp
   Response:
   Pt remained on 100% high flow neb with Sp02 94% but began to drop to
   88-90%, placed back on NRB. [**Name (NI) **] pt needs frequent reminders to focus on
   deep breathing and little talking. Fine crackles remain at bases. Dry
   cough persists, tiny amount of sputum with blood coughed up early but
   it was after blood from nose from 02- no sputum produced since
   Plan:
   Continue with broad coverage Abx as ? source of PNA continues. Unclear
   of etiology behind hypoxemia, possibly could be viral or bacteria PNA,
   advanced ILD. Follow temp curve. Follow CT results. Encouraged OOB, IS,
   CDB. Wean supplemental 02 as tolerated. Question of bronch
   Renal failure, acute (Acute renal failure, ARF)
   Assessment:
   Bun 38, Cr 2.2. UO 50 cc/hr, urine yellow and clear. UA (+) WBC, RBC
   with casts, and protein.
   Action:
   Renal ultrasound. D/C ASA as renal wants to do a biopsy
   Response:
   UO remains marginal 30-50 cc/hr.
   Plan:
   Renal biopsy later this week. Monitor UO and lytes. ? due to myeloma
   work up needed
   Hematology consulted today to regarding ? multiple myeloma diagnosis-
   s/s suggestive of at this time chronic fatigue past few months, ARF,
   hypoxemia. Apparently pts PCP had been concerned about this prior to
   admission and was trying to coordinate a hematology consult. Skeletal
   survey done. BM biopsy  needed once resp status improves
   ON: pt has very poor access, currently 2 peripheral but hard to even
   stick for labs, PICC order in but team was told it could no be placed
   until Tuesday. ? A-line placement for lab draws and ABGs
